abstracts.cdata!:
The project's outcome is highly
            satisfactory, having achieved its development objectives.
            Project sustainability is likely. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are satisfactory: the Bank made a
            significant contribution to FYR Macedonia's recovery
            from the Kosovo crisis. The project signaled the beginning
            of a more productive phase of relations between the Bank
            Group and the country. Key lessons learned included the
            following: In an emergency project, where quick disbursement
            is crucial, the general principles of financial management
            cannot be strictly applied because they would delay
            disbursement. The QAG Quality at Entry Assessment concluded
            that a dated covenant might have been more appropriate
            rather than insisting that as a condition of effectiveness
            that independent auditors be retained, and noted that while
            appraisal to Board approval was achieved in less than 6
            weeks, Board approval to effectiveness took more than 2
            months. Also, for an emergency credit of this kind, more
            appropriate indicators of overall impact might have been the
            timeliness of the Bank response and the speed of
            disbursements, both of which were highly responsive to the
            country's needs. A final lesson is about the financial
            covenants in the Development Credit Agreement --in
            particular, the requirements of quarterly audits increased
            considerably the cost of project administration and implied
            that the project's financial management and internal
            control arrangements were insufficient.
